title-group.article-title: Prevalence and associated factors of acne among patients attending dermatovenereology outpatient department at the University of Gondar Comprehensive Specialized Hospital, Northwest Ethiopia, 2023

abstract.p: Acne is a widespread skin condition with both physical and psychological effects. Despite Acne is the eighth most common disease in the world, affecting roughly 9.4% of people worldwide, understanding the specific factors influencing acne remains a research challenge. University of Gondar Comprehensive Specialized Hospital (UGCSH) serves as a unique context to explore the epidemiology of acne within a distinct demographic. However, the evidence is limited about the magnitude of acne in this population. By addressing the identified gaps, the study contributes not only to improved patient care but also to the broader understanding of acne. This study aims to assess the prevalence of acne and associated factors among patients attending Dermatovenereology Out Patient Department (OPD) at UGCSH, Northwest Ethiopia, 2023. Institution based analytical cross sectional study design was employed in this study. A systematic random sampling technique was used to recruit a total of 390 participants who attended Dermatovenereology OPD at the UGCSH from September to November 2023. Data were collected by face to face interview and physical examination. The completed data were entered into Epi Info version 7 and analyzed using Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 21.0. Descriptive and binary logistic regression data analyses were done. Variables with a p-value of < 0.25 on bivariate analysis were taken to multivariable analysis model to measure Adjusted Odds Ratio (AOR) with 95% Confidence Interval (CI) after controlling potential confounders and a p-value < 0.05 was used to declare statistically significant associations. The overall prevalence of acne was 26.2% with 95%CI: (21.7%, 30.8%).Those in the age groups 16–20, 21–25 and 26–30 years [AOR: 9.6, 95% CI: (2.9, 31.8), AOR:4.8, 95% CI: (1.8, 13.2),and AOR:4, 95% CI: (1.5, 10.7)], respectively and using hair oil or pomade [AOR : 4.0, 95% CI: (1.8, 9.0)], first degree family history of acne [AOR = 5.1, 95% CI: (2.6, 9.9)], and increased milk intake [AOR:3.1, 95% CI: (1.6, 6.0)] were found to be statistically associated factors with acne. The prevalence of acne in UGCSH was 26.2%. Age (16–30 years), hair oil or pomade use, first degree family history of acne, and increased milk intake were found to be the commo risk factor for acne. It’s recommended to develop patient-centered interventions that consider the identified modifiable factors, providing treatment plans that encompass both medical and lifestyle considerations.

sec.title: Statement of the problem
sec.p: Acne vulgaris is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. The clinical lesions are non-inflammatory open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules and nodules of varying degree of inflammation and depth. The face, back and/or chest are the most frequently affected sites1. Acne can occur at any age, starting at birth with neonatal acne (presents in the first few weeks of life) and infantile acne (presents between 1 and 12 months) and extending into adulthood2. Globally the highest prevalence of acne occurs in adolescence where it may be diagnosed in 80% of all teenagers1.

The prevalence of acne in adolescents is higher in males, whereas it’s higher in females during adulthood2. Factors associated with the development of acne include dietary habits, stress, insulin resistance, body mass index, family history, smoking, and use of cosmetics1,3. Acne significantly affects individuals’ physical and psychosocial well-being. The majority of patients may only experience a brief course of acne, but for those who do, the aftereffects can last a lifetime and cause psychological distress and scarring, particularly in young people2. Successful treatment correlates with improvement of psychological factors in many cases1. Due to its lack of ethnic preference, acne is a significant global health concern and is ranked among the top 10 most common diseases worldwide4,5.

The Global Burden of Disease Project estimates the prevalence of acne at 9.4%, ranking it as the eighth most prevalent disease worldwide5. A large-scale community-based study was performed in China and a total of 17,345 inhabitants were included. It was discovered that 1,399 of them had acne. Less than 10% of the participants under the age of ten had acne, while 1.6% of those over ten had it. Once in the 19-year-old group, the prevalence rose quickly to 46.8%. It then gradually decreased with age after that. Acne was more common in men among participants in their late teens and early 20s, whereas it was more common in women in those over 30. In subjects with acne, 68.4% had mild; 26.0% had moderate and 5.6% had severe acne6. In a South Indian hospital-based study, 1.068% of participants had acne vulgaris7. In large community-based studies conducted in Germany8 and Egypt9 prevalence of acne was found to be 3.9% and 54%, respectively. Acne prevalence from household surveys ranged from 0.35% southwestern Ethiopia10 to 17% in the Iraqi city of Basrah11. The prevalence of Acne in hospital based studies have been reported to be 4.6% in Ghana12, 6.7% in Nigeria13, and 17.5% in South Africa14. In Ethiopia epidemiologic studies regarding prevalence of acne are of limited number. An institutional based cross sectional study conducted at Ayder referral hospital, Mekelle, prevalence of acne was found to be 19.4% and females accounted for 52.6% of the cases15.

Even though acne is known to be a common global problem there is still a lot to be done regarding clearly identifying the associated factors and the degree of their contribution so that a clear path for possible prevention and treatment could be undertaken. In Ethiopia, there have only been a few studies from different regions focusing on issues regarding prevalence of acne and associated factors. To the scope of the researcher, no similar study has been done at this study area. Hence, there is an unmet need regarding this field of study in this study area. Therefore, the aim of this study was to assess the prevalence and associated factors of acne among patients attending Dermatovenereology Out Patient Department at the University Of Gondar Comprehensive Specialized Hospital.

sec.title: General objective
sec.p: To assess the prevalence and associated factors of acne among patients attending Dermatovenereology OPD at University of Gondar Comprehensive Specialized Hospital, Gondar city, Northwest Ethiopia, 2023.

sec.title: Specific objectives
sec.p: To determine the prevalence of acne among patients attending Dermatovenereology OPD in the study area.
To identify factors associated with acne among patients attending Dermatovenereology OPD in the study area.

sec.title: Study design and period
sec.p: An institutional based analytical cross sectional study design was used to assess the problem of acne from September to November 2023.

sec.title: Study setting
sec.p: The study was conducted at the UGCSH Dermatovenereology OPD. It is located in Central Gondar administrative zone, Amhara National Regional state, which is about 750 km Northwest of Addis Ababa (the capital city of Ethiopia). According to the recent administration, Gondar city has 21 kebeles with a population of 358,257 people. Currently, the city has one governmental specialized and teaching hospital, one governmental general hospital, 8 governmental health centers, and two private hospitals. The UGCSH is a teaching hospital that serves more than five million people in the Central Gondar zone and adjacent areas. It provides a wide range of medical services. As the only institution with dermatologists in and around Gondar, it is responsible for most of the dermatologic complaints in these areas.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: All patients attending Dermatovenereology OPD at the UGCSH during study period.

sec.title: Inclusion criteria
sec.p: Patients with age 11–50 years attending Dermatovenereology OPD at the UGCSH and available during data collection period who have consented to participate in the study.

sec.title: Exclusion criteria
sec.p: Patients with drug-induced and other acneiform eruptions.
All patients attending Dermatovenereology OPD at the UGCSH during study period.

sec.title: Sample size determination
sec.p: Considering the proportion of acne as 19.4% from a study conducted in Ayder Hospital, Mekelle15, a sample of 414 patients (using single population proportion sample size calculation formula for cross sectional study) were included in this research project with the following assumptions: an assumed 19.4% proportion of acne among Dermatovenereology OPD patients; a confidence level of 95%; a marginal error of 4%.
Where:
n = the desired sample size.
P = the proportion of occurrence of acne, 19.4%.
1-P = proportion of clients free from acne, 1-0.194 = 0.806 = 80.6%.
Zα/2 = Critical value for normal distribution at 95% confidence level which equals to 1.96 (α = 0.05).
d = the margin of error taken at 4% (0.04).
The formula yielded 376 sample size and adding 10% (38 clients) for non-response rate. The total minimum sample size was 414.

sec.title: Sampling technique and procedure
sec.p: Systematic random sampling was used to select study units from patients attending the Dermatovenereology OPD until the required sample size was achieved.

In average, 25 patients visit the Dermatovenereology OPD daily from Monday up to Friday working hours. Last year within three months period (September, October, and November), a total of 1830 patients were seeking treatment for different skin disorders.

Kth-value was the number of total patients within the study period divided by the total sample size = 1830/414 = 4.2 = 4. In this study we included every 4th patient coming to dermatology OPDs. Then the selected patients were studied by interview (history), and clinical examination (Physical examination).

sec.title: Operational definitions
sec.p: Acne. Diagnosed by a trained data-collecting Dermatovenereology resident.

Stress. Is the means by which the body‘s coping mechanism adapts to external stimuli and change in the environment. The degree of stress in a person’s life will be measured by perceived stress scale (PSS), which contains 10 questions (see annex 2)16.
Individual scores on the PSS can range from 0 to 40 with higher scores indicating higher perceived stress.

list-item.p: Scores ranging from 0 to 13 would be considered low stress.
Scores ranging from 14 to 26 would be considered moderate stress.
Scores ranging from 27 to 40 would be considered high perceived stress.

sec.p:
Diet habit17:
Increased intake of sweets/cake: more than 3 days/week.
Increased intake of milk: more than 3 days/week.
Increased intake of chocolate: more than 3 days/week.

BMI: Weight and height measurement will be taken and BMI will be calculated by dividing weight in Kg for height in m². BMI categories could be interpreted as follows: <18.5 kg/ m2: underweight or at risk of underweight, 18.5 to 23 kg/m2: normal weight, and > 23 kg/m2: overweight or at risk of overweight18.

sec.title: Data collection procedures
sec.p: Data were collected by five Dermatovenereology residents after a one day training was given on how to document relevant information on the questionnaire related to the study.
All patients selected by systematic random sampling were interviewed; patient history and physical examination was undertaken.

sec.title: Data processing and analysis
sec.p: Data were coded first and entered using Epi Info version 7 for data exploration and cleaning. The cleaned data were exported to SPSS version 27.0.1 software for statistical analysis. Descriptive and analytic statistics were calculated19. The descriptive statistics were described using frequency, percentage, mean and standard deviation by figure, table and text. After Binary logistic regression analysis crude and adjusted odds ratio with the corresponding confidence interval and P-value were computed using bivariate and multi variable logistic regression, respectively. All explanatory variables in bivariate analysis with p-value of less than 0.25 were considered candidate variables for multivariable analysis to control confounding factors. The model fitness was assessed using Hosmer and Lemeshow’s goodness of fit test https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=goodness+of+fit+test+in+binary+logistic+regression+analysis&btnG=#:~:text=Exact%20goodness%2Dof%2Dfit%20test%20for%20binary%20logistic%20model. A p-value less than 0.05 was used to report statistically significant variables in this study.

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: Ethical clearance was obtained from the institutional review board of University of Gondar, College of Medicine and Health Sciences and permission was obtained from the department of Dermatovenereology. Assent for patients aged less than 18 years and consent for those aged 18 years and above were taken from all study participants and parents (guardians). They were adequately informed with regard to the aim and importance of the study along with their right to refuse for participation before proceeding with the questions. Information obtained from the participants was kept confidential by using anonymous questionnaires.

sec.title: Data quality control
sec.p: Training was given to the data collectors and pre-test was done before the actual data collection period on up to 20 participants (5% of total sample size). In addition, data collection procedure was closely supervised by the PI and any error was corrected on time.

sec.title: Socio-demographic characteristics
sec.p: A total of 414 participants were included in this study and 390 respondents completed the responses with a response rate of 94.2%. The mean (± SD) age of respondents was 27.0 (± 8.3) years. 211 (54.1%) of the respondents were females and 179 (45.9%) were males while 372(95.4%) of the respondents were Orthodox Christians by religion and 17 (4.4%) were Muslims. Among the total respondents 198 (50.8%) were single and 179 (45.9%) were married.

Students constituted the largest occupational status (32.8%) followed by government employees (23.8%). Regarding educational status, 134 (34.4%) respondents have educational status of secondary school and 126 (32.3%) have accomplished tertiary education. More than two third (69.2%) of them were from urban area and the median (IQR) monthly family income was 4,000 birr (2,300 birr to 7,000 birr) (Table 1).

sec.title: Personal and clinical characteristics
sec.p: First degree family history of acne was reported in 66 (16.9%) of the respondents while hair oil or pomade use and cigarette smoking were reported in 47 (12.1%) and 4 (1.0%) of the respondents, respectively. Regarding dietary habit, increased intake of sweats/cake, milk and chocolate was reported in 22 (5.6%), 83 (21.3%), 14 (3.6%) of the respondents respectively. The majority of the study participants (88.2%) were found to have low perceived stress while the rest (11.8%) had moderate perceived stress, and the majority (77.9%) had BMI within the normal range (18.5–23) (Table 2).

sec.title: Occurrence of acne
sec.p: Among the 390 respondents of the study, 102 (26.2%) respondents had acne on physical examination and among these, 18 (17.6%) of them had history of treatment for their skin lesion. Mean duration of acne was 23.3 months and the range was 1 month to 6 years. Of the 102 patients, 59 (57.8%) were females and 43 (42.2%) were males (Fig. 1). Regarding the primary morphology of the lesions, 93 (91.2%) of individuals with acne had comedones, 90 (88.2%) had papules, 23 (22.5%) had pustules and only 3 (2.9%) had nodules. Face was found to be involved in 101 (99%) of patients, while chest and back involvement was seen in 32 (31.4%) and 27 (25.2%) of the patients, respectively (Table 3).

sec.title: Factors associated with acne
sec.p: In the final multivariable logistic regression analysis, among the ten candidate variables only four resisted the final model. Age, hair oil or pomade use, first-degree family history of acne and increased intake of milk were significantly associated factors with acne.

Young age group categories 16–20, 21–25 and 26–30 were 9.6 [AOR: 9.6, 95% CI: (2.9, 31.8)], 4.8 [AOR: 4.8, 95% CI: (1.8, 13.2)], and 4 [AOR: 4, 95% CI: (1.5, 10.7)] times more likely, respectively, to have acne than those aged > 30 years.

The odds of experiencing acne among individuals who used hair oil or pomade was four times more likely than those who didn’t [AOR: 4, 95% CI: (1.8, 9.0)]. Individuals with a first-degree family history of acne exhibited a fivefold higher likelihood of developing acne compared to those without such history [AOR: 5.1, 95% CI: (2.6, 9.9)]. Furthermore, patients who reported an increased intake of milk demonstrated a threefold higher odds of experiencing acne compared to their counterparts [AOR: 3.1, 95% CI: (1.6, 6)] (Table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The study identified that the prevalence of acne was 26.2% (95%CI; 21.7, 30.8) and in factor analysis, our study findings revealed that age, hair oil or pomade use, first-degree family history of acne, and increased intake of milk were significantly associated with acne.

Our study revealed a higher prevalence compared to similar institution-based investigations conducted across diverse locations, like 19.2% in Mekelle, Ethiopia15, 6.7% in Nigeria13, 5.3% in Senegal20, and 17.5% in South Africa14. However, it is lower by a maximum of two-fold compared to the prevalence rates observed in Middle Eastern countries, including 45% in Jordan21, 34% in Syria22 and 56.2% in Saudi Arabia23. The observed variation in acne prevalence may be attributed to a complex interplay of genetic factors and environmental influences, both of which have been implicated as contributors to acne susceptibility18,24. Additionally, dissimilarities in socio-demographic profiles among study participants could exert an influential role. Noteworthy factors influencing the disparities in acne prevalence across studies encompass variations in study design, pubertal onset, lifestyle, skin type, and cosmetic usage25.

Our data revealed a heightened likelihood of acne occurrence among adolescents and young adults aged 16–30 years. Notably, those in the 16–20 age group were the most likely to be affected, constituting 32.4% of the total affected individuals. This observation aligns with consistent findings in diverse global regions, including Mekelle, Ethiopia15, China6, India7, and Europe26. Additionally, a comprehensive study comparing acne prevalence and subtypes in women across four ethnicities further substantiates this age-related association27. The heightened susceptibility to acne development during adolescence is attributed to the elevated production of androgens. Androgens have been identified as pivotal factors in acne pathogenesis, as they stimulate the sebaceous glands to produce more sebum. This increased sebum production plays a critical role in acne development, thereby escalating the likelihood of its manifestation during this particular life stage1–3.

Different studies have revealed the association of hair oil or pomade use with increased risk of having acne, particularly in individuals with skin of color28–30. Our study showed that those who use hair oil or pomade were four times more likely to have acne than those who don’t, in agreement with the aforementioned studies. Pomades are greasy preparations used to defrizz curly hair, and can trigger non-inflammatory acne by occluding follicular orifices, thereby promoting acne lesion formation1,29.

Our study revealed that the odd of experiencing acne among patients with first degree family history of acne was five times higher than those without. This finding aligns with corroborative evidence from diverse international studies, including those done in Mekelle, Ethiopia15, China31, Italy18, and the UK24,32. The consistent convergence of results across these geographically distinct studies reinforces the hereditary influence on acne susceptibility.

Elevated levels of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) associated with the consumption of dairy or diets with a high glycemic load, along with the presence of natural hormonal components and bioactive molecules in milk, are hypothesized to contribute to the development of acne17,18,33. In this study, the risk of having acne increased threefold among individuals with increased milk intake (consuming more than three portions per week). This finding is in concordance with supporting evidence from studies conducted in varied regions, encompassing the USA and Nigeria33, Italy17,18, and the UK28.

sec.title: Strength and limitation of the study
sec.p: The study’s strengths lie in its contribution to understanding the prevalence and associated factors of acne among patients at UGCSH, Northwest Ethiopia. The use of systematic random sampling increases the representativeness of the sample, contributing to the reliability of the study’s results. Additionally, the study’s emphasis on addressing modifiable factors adds practical value to the research contributing to improved treatment plans.

The study’s limitations may include the use of a cross-sectional design, which limits establishing causality between associated factors and acne. Additionally, the reliance on self-reported data for variables like diet and family history may introduce recall bias. The study’s focus on a specific demographic at UGCSH in Northwest Ethiopia may limit the generalizability of the findings to other populations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The prevalence of acne in UGCSH was 26.2%. Age (16–30 years), hair oil or pomade use, first degree family history of acne, and increased milk intake were found to be the commo risk factor for acne. It’s recommended to develop patient-centered interventions that consider the identified modifiable factors, providing treatment plans that encompass both medical and lifestyle considerations.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors acknowledge all the specialized referral hospitals, data collectors, supervisors, and study participants.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Author’s contribution: Dr. Zelalem Kassa: Made a strong contribution to the conception, design, analysis, writing the manuscript, and interpretation of data.Dr. Abebe Sinknew, and Dr. Bikes Destaw Bitew: Took part in drafting the article or revising it critically for important intellectual content; Mr. Esayas Alemshet Tekletsadik: Took part in drafting the article or revising it critically for important intellectual content;

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: No funding was received for the conduction of the study or the preparation of the manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: Availability of data and materials: Upon a reasonable request, all the data are available on the corresponding author.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethical approval and informed consent
notes.p: The study was conducted after ethical approval was obtained from the Ethical Review Committee of the University of Gondar, College of Medicine and health science; on behalf of the Institutional Review Board (IRB). Permission letters were obtained from the management committee University of Gondar Comprehensive Specialized Hospital,. Finally, informed consent was obtained from all the participants, and participants were assured of the confidentiality of the information, and the data were collected anonymously. Any inconvenience to participants during data collection was minimized. All methods were carried out following relevant guidelines and regulations.
